qas.question: Who thought that Burke's imitation was too perfect to be effective ridicule?
Why did a few scholars think Burke hadn't intended his book as a satire yet later claimed it was a satire?
What did Richard Hurd claim made Burke's satire perfect?
What is the name of one of the scholars who believe Burke wrote the Vindication in earnest?
What is the name of the book Richard Hurd wrote?
Why did Hurd believe Burke's imitation was near perfect?
Whose principles did L. Bol imitate?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>Richard Hurd<b4_0/><a0_0/> believed that <b3_0><b7_0>Burke's<b7_0/> imitation<b3_0/> was near-perfect and that this defeated his purpose: an ironist "should take care by a constant exaggeration to make the ridicule shine through the Imitation. Whereas this <b5_0>Vindication<b5_0/> is everywhere enforc'd, not only in the language, and on the principles of <a2_0>L. Bol.<a2_0/>, but with so apparent, or rather so real an earnestness, that half his purpose is sacrificed to the other". A minority of scholars have taken the position that, in fact, Burke did write the Vindication in earnest, later disowning it only for <a1_0><b6_0>political reasons<b6_0/><a1_0/>.
